Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_community_planning_program
Datasets.Description: The Regional Plan establishes long-range, region-wide planning policies outlining where, when, and how future growth and development should take place. The Regional Plan also establishes the Community Planning Program, which will reorganize HRM’s current planning framework into three geographies, the Regional Centre, Suburban Area and  Rural Area. This dataset serves to reference document for these three Regional Plan Areas, providing users spatial and temporal dimensions to support plan review processes and inform decision makers.
Datasets.Summary: The polygon features within this dataset identify the specific Regional Plan Area applicable to distinct areas within the Municipality. The dataset also serves as an reference source for POSSE, providing information and context for planning and permitting reviews.
Datasets.Purpose: The polygon features within this dataset identify the specific Regional Plan Area applicable to distinct areas within the Municipality. The dataset also serves as an reference source for POSSE, providing information and context for planning and permitting reviews.
Datasets.Tags: Regional Plan, Centre Plan, Suburban Plan, Rural Plan, Regional Plan Boundaries
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: The Regional Plan establishes long-range, region-wide planning policies outlining where, when, and h… | Tags: Regional Plan, Centre Plan, Suburban Plan, Rural Plan, Regional Plan Boundaries

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_electoral_district_ns
Datasets.Description: The electoral district names and boundaries are based on amendments to the House of Assembly Act passed on December 6, 2012 (Chapter 61 of the Acts of 2012) and passed on May 10, 2013 (Chapters 10 and 19 to 23 of the Acts of 2013). The electoral district boundaries take effect on the dissolution of the 61st House of Assembly for the 39th General Election since Confederation.
Datasets.Summary: Digital representation of electoral geography for Nova Scotia, used to support the electoral process.
Datasets.Purpose: Digital representation of electoral geography for Nova Scotia, used to support the electoral process.
Datasets.Tags: electoral district, electoral geography
Datasets.UseConstraints: Elections Nova Scotia (ENS) grants to the user of this data set a royalty-free , non-exclusive use of the digital geographic data. The user has no ownership rights in the geographic data. Ownership of the geographic data and all intellectual property rights therein, if any, shall remain at all times with ENS. The user is authorized to use the geographic data solely for its own internal operation with respect to its specific needs. Reproduction or redistribution of copyrighted geographic data outside of user's organization or entity is expressly forbidden unless prior permission is granted by ENS.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_gflum_regplan
Datasets.Description: There are seven general land us designations which form the framework for achieving the growth management strategy of the Halifax Regional Plan. Urban Settlement, Urban Reserve, Rural Settlement, Rural Commuter, Rural Resource, Agriculturaland Open Space and Natural Resource. The centres have been defined and strategically located where services such as transit, wastewater and water can be economically and efficiently provided. One quarter of the predicted growth will occur within the Regional Centre, and half will be directed towards suburban areas. Policies regarding management of large subdivision development, island development, and the provision of incentives for redevelopment of abandoned and underutilised properties, are additional growth management mechanisms outlined in this Plan.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_growth_control_area
Datasets.Description: Physical boundary of the Beaver Bank / Hammonds Plains Growth Control Areas
Datasets.Summary: Until a substantive change is made in the infrastructure capacity within the Hammonds Plains and Beaver Bank areas, due to the safety concerns stated in section 4.1.1.4, it is appropriate to limit all further residential subdivision activity involving new public roads in these areas. As provided for by the Municipal Government Act, existing plans of residential subdivision, at the tentative or final plan of subdivision stage on or before the effective date of this Plan, shall be permitted to proceed through to completion.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.ADM_transportation_analysis_zone
Datasets.Description: This polygon feature class contains Transportation Analysis Zones covering the HRM and Joint Regional Transportation Agency (JRTA) area. Transportation Analysis Zones are geographical areas utilized in transportation planning to model and analyze travel behavior, patterns, and infrastructure needs. The layer was created by Transportation Planning in January 2023.
Datasets.Summary: TAZs play a pivotal role in transportation planning and analysis, offering a spatial framework for understanding travel demand, evaluating transportation systems, and shaping policy and investment decisions aimed at improving mobility, accessibility, and sustainability. This dataset serves as a reference layer for future studies and is utilized in various internal web applications for symbolization purposes. These geographies form the foundation for HRM's travel demand model.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.AST_green_cart
Datasets.Description:
Points representing green carts used for organic waste collection.

All the historical green cart files and monthly updates from the live Hansen records have been combined into one file geographically referenced to civic addresses (CIVID). Each cart record is represented by a point and reflect the history of deliveries, repairs and removals. At a particular civic address there may be no cart record (not a residential property), one or many cart records. Certain records have been flagged as being of known suspicious quality.
Datasets.Summary: This file was created at the request of Solid Waste to help them manage the green cart assets. The intention is to allow Solid Waste to validate the appropriateness of the records before the cart data is make public. There are error flags associated with certain records to enable Solid Waste to identify the records that are definitely suspicious in quality. When it is decided to publish this data to a wider audience a thorough evaluation of the best distribution method will be made.
Datasets.Purpose: This file was created at the request of Solid Waste to help them manage the green cart assets. When it is decided to publish this data to a wider audience a thorough evaluation of the best distribution method will be made.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.AST_pavement_rating
Datasets.Description: Linear representation of HRM owned or maintained street inventory and condition rating data as collected by the Infrastructure Management Services section of TPW.
Datasets.Summary: Infrastructure Management Services is a section of Design and Construction that manages the street surface infrastructure of T&PW. We maintain an inventory of HRM owned or maintained streets, and inspect these streets using a Pavement Condition Management System. These ratings are used to develop capital projects and provide network level analysis on these assets. The computer program enables us to see how these various asset conditions change over time depending on the amount of money allocated in the Capital Budget. We can also run various computer simulations on the various networks using different budget and rehabilitation scenarios to determine how we can get the most assets rehabilitated for the least amount of money.
Datasets.Purpose: Infrastructure Management Services is a section of Design and Construction that manages the street surface infrastructure of T&PW. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_socio_economic_indicators
Datasets.Description:
The Community Environs (COMe) geographies represent clusters of population and neighborhoods sharing identity and social processes, including access to healthcare services. This feature class includes the Material Security (MS) and Social Connectivity (SC) Indicators, which are composite measures of socio-economic conditions experienced by communities. These indicators are derived from census data, showing 5 levels of security and connectivity based on PCA without age standardization.

Variables contributing to the Material Security indicator (MS):

- % Low Education Level

- % Unemployment Rate

- Average Individual Income, $

- % Incidence Low Income After Tax (20-64 years)

- % Incidence Low Income After Tax (65+ years)

- % Government Transfer Payments

- % Spend 30% Income on Shelter

- % Living in Household in need of Major Repairs

- Average Value of Dwelling

Variables contributing to the Social Connectivity indicator (SC):

- % Separated, Divorced, Widowed

- % Single Parent Families

- % Person Living Alone

- % Recent Movers

- % Recent Immigrant

- % Speaking no Official Language at Home

- % Visible Minority

These variables were used to create quintiles for both MS and SC, ranging from 1 (low security/connectivity) to 5 (high security/connectivity). The methodology follows the Deprivation Index of Canada, without age standardization, and with MS and SC derived from two independent PCA processes.

Other variables of interest not included in the area-based SES summary indicators:

- Population Count

- Female Population

- Male Population

- Average Age

- Median Individual Income, $

- % Renter

- % Subhousing

- % Refugee

- % Population 65+, living alone

- % Population age 0-9

- % Population age 20-29

- % Population age 50-74

- % Population aged 65 years and older

These variables, while not part of the SES (Socio-Economic Status) summary indicators, provide additional insights into the demographics and living conditions within the COMe geographies.
Datasets.Summary: This feature class contains indicators of Material Security (MS) and Social Connectivity (SC) for Community Environs (COMe), reflecting socio-economic conditions based on census data. MS and SC indicators are derived from census variables using principal component analysis (PCA) and grouped into quintiles to reflect community well-being.
Datasets.Purpose: This feature class contains indicators of Material Security (MS) and Social Connectivity (SC) for Community Environs (COMe), reflecting socio-economic conditions based on census data. MS and SC indicators are derived from census variables using principal component analysis (PCA) and grouped into quintiles to reflect community well-being.

Datasets.Credits: Some data is derived from Statistics Canada. Adapted by Dr. Nathalie Saint-Jacques (Nova Scotia Health), based on data from the Census Profile. Statistics Canada is not responsible for the derivation, interpretation, or analysis of the data.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.FLD_fp_StudyAreas
Datasets.Description:
This dataset consolidates modeled floodplain extents from multiple hydrologic and climate resilience studies conducted across select watersheds in the Halifax Regional Municipality. Included are flood risk extents for:

- Sackville River & Little Sackville River (CBCL 2017, DesignPoint 2024)

- Shubenacadie Lakes region (CBCL 2020)

Polygons represent modeled flood plains for various return periods (e.g., 1 in 20 year, 1 in 100 year), with relevant hydrologic and climate parameters captured in the attribute fields. All data support planning and development processes and are not intended to represent official regulatory boundaries.

Each polygon includes a case study identifier (e.g., “SR”, “SL”) and model-specific information including AEP, return period, projection horizon, storm event characteristics, and source information among other specifications.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representations of modeled floodplain extents for select Halifax watersheds including the Sackville River system and the Shubenacadie Lakes. Compiled from multiple case studies to support land use planning and climate adaptation.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representations of modeled floodplain extents for select Halifax watersheds including the Sackville River system and the Shubenacadie Lakes. Compiled from multiple case studies to support land use planning and climate adaptation.
Datasets.Tags: Halifax, Sackville River, Little Sackville River, Shubenacadie Lakes, Lake Charles, Portobello, Flooding, Floodplain, Planning, Development, Halifax Open Data, Climate Change, LiDAR, Watershed, AEP, 2100, 2020, 2017, 2024
Datasets.Credits:
- Sackville River Floodplain Study – Phase II, CBCL Limited, 2017
- Sackville River Floodplain Update, DesignPoint Engineering & Surveying, 2024
- Shubenacadie Lakes Floodplain Study, CBCL Limited, 2020
Datasets.UseConstraints: To be used for Land Use Planning purposes only. This dataset reflects modeled outputs from engineering studies and does not represent regulatory boundaries or approved policies. Consult the original study documents for further detail.

Datasets.Description: Halifax Water’s ‘Water Supply Sheds’ are defined by natural watershed delineations to the point of the water intake. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_ANS_communities
Datasets.Description: This polygon feature class comprises the polygon boundaries of African Nova Scotian Communities within the municipality. The dataset delineates the spatial extent of these communities, providing planners and decision-makers with geospatial information essential for strategic planning and development initiatives. By leveraging this dataset, stakeholders can identify and map the designated African Nova Scotian Communities, facilitating targeted interventions to foster inclusive growth, economic prosperity, and community well-being.
Datasets.Summary: On April 4, 2023, the Regional Council endorsed the 2023-26 updated Road to Economic Prosperity for African Nova Scotian Communities: Summary Report and Action Plan (REPAC), marking a significant milestone in the municipality's commitment to fostering healthy, livable communities and promoting economic development. This endorsement underscores a coordinated effort outlined in the Halifax Economic Growth Plan 2016-2021 to achieve tangible and measurable results in African Nova Scotian Communities. The purpose of this dataset is to support this commitment by providing spatial data to planners and decision-makers.
Datasets.Purpose: On April 4, 2023, the Regional Council endorsed the 2023-26 updated Road to Economic Prosperity for African Nova Scotian Communities: Summary Report and Action Plan (REPAC), marking a significant milestone in the municipality's commitment to fostering healthy, livable communities and promoting economic development. This endorsement underscores a coordinated effort outlined in the Halifax Economic Growth Plan 2016-2021 to achieve tangible and measurable results in African Nova Scotian Communities. The purpose of this dataset is to support this commitment by providing spatial data to planners and decision-makers.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_area_rate_fire_protection
Datasets.Description: Boundary delineating the parcels within one kilometer of any fire hydrant used for fire protection. Some hydrants such as the the one in Musquodoboit are for flushing only, and are therefore excluded from this faeture class. This layer was generated using Network Analyst, creating a network service line 1200 feet less 50 metres from every hydrant point. The service line was then buffered by 50 metres. This was done to intersect all parcels on either side of a right-of-way, including wide boulevards and cul-de-sacs. The 50 metre buffer does present some problems of intersecting the backs of parcels through the shorter lots. Upon having all the intersected parcels, they were merged together, and has topology rules applied to avoid gaps and overlaps. Water courses and/or crown land that was "land-locked" by the merged parcels were incorporated into the boundary. Water courses and/or crown lands that were on the fringe of the merged parcels were removed to reduce the size of the boundary layer. Where appropriate, parcels not intersected by the service line buffer, but that are clearly serviced within one kilometre are included. These may include adjoining water lots that share the same AAN.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_business_park
Datasets.Description: The Business Parks Functional Plan is one of the mechanisms for implementing HRM’s Regional Municipal Planning Strategy, which was approved in 2006. The Business Parks Functional Plan (BPFP) serves as a strategic plan for the future expansion of business parks and ensuring adequate supply of industrial lands within HRM. There are thirteen (13) business parks in HRM owned by the municipality and the province, plus an additional three owned by the private sector. The HRM owns and operates six (6) business parks in HRM (Burnside, City of Lakes, Bayers Lake, Aerotech, Ragged Lake, and Lakeside), while the Province manages seven (7) parks (Sackville, Woodside, Atlantic Acres, Bedford, Eastern Shore, Musquodoboit Harbour and Sheet Harbour) through Nova Scotia Business Inc. (NSBI). The three privately owned parks in HRM Dartmouth Crossing, Bedford Commons, and West Bedford Business Campus, include a total of 950 acres of land, and focus on providing for retail and office uses.
Datasets.Summary: Created to depict the location of business parks and industrial parks.
Datasets.Purpose: Created to depict the location of business parks and industrial parks.
Datasets.Tags: County, park, commercial, Bedford, Dartmouth, HRM, industrial, Sackville, Halifax Regional Municipality, business, Halifax
Datasets.UseConstraints: This information has been collected and/or procured for the internal use of HRM staff (and its agencies) and may not be distributed externally without consulting the proper authorities.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_elevated_arch_potential
Datasets.Description: Archaeological resources are the remains of any building, structure, activity, place or cultural feature or object that, because of the passage of time, is on or below the surface of land or water and is of significance to the understanding of the history of a people or place. These sites are protected under provincial legislation, the Special Places Protection Act, which regulates the destruction, alteration or removal of archaeological resources from these sites.
Datasets.Summary: In conjunction with the Heritage Division of the Nova Scotia Department of Tourism, Culture and Heritage, HRM has prepared the Areas of Elevated Archaeological Potential Map (Map 11) to identify areas with high potential to contain archaeological resources from the period of time preceding European settlement. The development of these sites could present a significant risk to archaeological resources. If these sites are recognized and appropriately addressed prior to development taking place, adverse consequences can be mitigated and archaeological resources preserved.
Datasets.Purpose: In conjunction with the Heritage Division of the Nova Scotia Department of Tourism, Culture and Heritage, HRM has prepared the Areas of Elevated Archaeological Potential Map (Map 11) to identify areas with high potential to contain archaeological resources from the period of time preceding European settlement. If these sites are recognized and appropriately addressed prior to development taking place, adverse consequences can be mitigated and archaeological resources preserved.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_floodplain_overlay
Datasets.Description: The Floodway Overlay Zones and the Areas Requiring Modified Floodproofing are overlaying existing zones to help implement floodplain protection polices outlined within each plan. The 1 in 20 year Floodway Overlay (FWO) Zone, the 1 in 100 year Flood Fringe Overlay (FFO) Zone, and the Modified Floodproofing (MFP) measures help delineate areas of controlled development and constraints in land use planning within the Sackville and Little Sackville River areas.
Datasets.Summary: Polygon representation of the Floodplain Overlay Zones and Areas Requiring Modified Floodproofing within the Sackville and Little Sackville River area, which delineates areas of controlled development and constraints based on 2024 floodplain study.
Datasets.Purpose: Polygon representation of the Floodplain Overlay Zones and Areas Requiring Modified Floodproofing within the Sackville and Little Sackville River area, which delineates areas of controlled development and constraints based on 2024 floodplain study.
Datasets.Tags: Floodplain Overlay Zones, Sackville River, Little Sackville River, Floodway Fringe, Modified Floodproofing
Datasets.Credits: Created by HRM Planning & Development. Policy boundaries informed by the Sackville Rivers Floodplain Study (CBCL, 2017) and 2024 model update (DesignPoint).
Datasets.UseConstraints: This dataset is for planning reference only and does not replace official zoning or regulatory maps. Users should verify data accuracy with HRM Planning and Development. Not to be used for property-level decision-making without consulting official land use documents.
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: The Floodway Overlay Zones and the Areas Requiring Modif… | Tags: Floodplain Overlay Zones, Sackville River, Little Sackville River, Floodway Fringe, Modified Floodproofing

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_indigenous_lands
Datasets.Description:
This dataset captures lands where title is either:

- vested through legislation or land claim agreements, or

- identified through internal processes as Indigenous-owned or under Indigenous stewardship, though not necessarily defined under federal or provincial Acts.

It includes Legislated Aboriginal Lands (federally used terminology), such as Indian Reserves (as per the Indian Act), and further, if applicable: Land claim settlement lands, other specific legislated areas.

It further includes Indigenous-Owned Lands:

- Lands identified by internal consultation or other sources as being owned, managed, or held in trust for Indigenous groups, but not captured by formal legislative boundaries.

- These may include lands purchased, gifted, or recognized by Indigenous entities, and are typically confirmed through parcel identification and land registry references.

The dataset supports reconciliation, land use planning, planning projects, and decision-making efforts. This is maintained by the Office of Diversity and Inclusion.

The use of some of the data does not imply endorsement by the Government of Canada. Any interpretations or decisions made based on this data are the sole responsibility of the user.
Datasets.Summary:
The Indigenous Lands feature class consists of polygon features depicting lands associated with Indigenous groups in Halifax Regional Municipality, including both legislated administrative boundaries (e.g. reservation lands) and Indigenous-owned lands.

Contains information licensed under the Open Government Licence – Canada.
Source: Aboriginal Lands of Canada Legislative Boundaries, retrieved from https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/522b07b9-78e2-4819-b736-ad9208eb1067
Datasets.Purpose:
The Indigenous Lands feature class consists of polygon features depicting lands associated with Indigenous groups in Halifax Regional Municipality, including both legislated administrative boundaries (e.g. reservation lands) and Indigenous-owned lands.

Contains information licensed under the Open Government Licence – Canada.
Source: Aboriginal Lands of Canada Legislative Boundaries, retrieved from https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/522b07b9-78e2-4819-b736-ad9208eb1067
Datasets.Tags: Indigenous Lands, First Nations, Indian Reserves, Settlement Lands, Indigenous-Owned Land, Land Use Planning, DEI, Reconciliation, Land Stewardship, Territorial Rights, Administrative Boundaries, Indigenous Reserve Lands
Datasets.Credits:
"This dataset is compiled and maintained by the Diversity, Equity & Inclusion (DEI) Office in collaboration with the P&D and GIS.

Source data is derived from:
- Provincial and federal open data portals, including legislated reserve boundaries and land claim settlement areas.
- Internal land registry analysis and engagements to identify Indigenous-owned parcels not reflected in public legislative datasets.
- Contributions from subject matter experts and engagement with key partners.

The dataset leverages information developed and maintained by:
- Natural Resources Canada (NRCan)
- Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs Canada (CIRNAC)
- Provincial geospatial authorities

Contains information licensed under the Open Government License – Canada.
Source: Aboriginal Lands of Canada Legislative Boundaries, retrieved from https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/522b07b9-78e2-4819-b736-ad9208eb1067"
Datasets.UseConstraints:
"This dataset is provided for planning, policy, and reference purposes only and does not constitute legal land status.

Users are responsible for validating boundaries and classifications with authoritative sources before use in legal or transactional contexts.

Portions of this dataset contain information licensed under the Open Government License – Canada. You may:

- Copy, modify, publish, translate, adapt, distribute, or otherwise use the Information for any lawful purpose, including commercial use,

- Provided that attribution is maintained as described under the license terms.

This license does not permit:

- Use of personal information,

- Third-party rights the Information Provider cannot license,

- Use of official symbols, logos, or endorsements,

- Any assertion of official status or endorsement by the Government of Canada.

The data is provided ""as is"" without warranty or liability."

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_outdoor_rec_poly
Datasets.Description:
Polygons representing outdoor recreation areas such active use areas (playgrounds, , sportsfields, sportscourts, ball diamonds and water-related activity areas.

LND_outdoor_rec_poly has a relationship class to the LND_outdoor_rec_use table. The relationship links assets to the use(s) of those assets, e.g., a sportscourt is used as a basketball court.

LND_outdoor_rec_poly has a relationship class to the LND_outdoor_rec_equip_point feature class. The relationship links assets such as sportscourts (polygons) to basketball hoops (points).

LND_outdoor_rec_poly has a relationship to LND_park_recreation_feature, which identifies outdoor recreation polygon assets or groups of assets for mapping purposes.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_special_planning_areas
Datasets.Description: This dataset was created to support the development of Provincial Special Planning Areas (SPAs) designated under the Housing in the Halifax Regional Municipality Act. The dataset delineates these areas from other lands not covered by the Act. These areas were established to accelerate housing supply by granting the Minister of Growth and Development authority over planning decisions within them.
Datasets.Summary: The Province of Nova Scotia has created an Executive Panel on Housing to address housing challenges in the capital region. As part of this initiative, the Minister of Growth and Development has designated Provincial Special Planning Areas (SPAs) within the Halifax Regional Municipality. This dataset represents the boundaries of those areas.
Datasets.Purpose: The Province of Nova Scotia has created an Executive Panel on Housing to address housing challenges in the capital region. This dataset represents the boundaries of those areas.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.LND_zoning
Datasets.Description:
Land use zone applied to a particular area of land within a land use by-law (LUB) area. The zone value of each polygon corresponds with a zone in the associated land use by-law, which lists permitted or prohibited uses for each zone.

Land use zones differ between LUB areas, so each zone must be interpreted within the context of the LUB area in which it is applied.
Datasets.Summary: To determine permitted or prohibited land uses according to the provisions of the land use by-laws within HRM.
Datasets.Purpose: To determine permitted or prohibited land uses according to the provisions of the land use by-laws within HRM.

Complete information for each land use by-law is available from HRM Development Approvals.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.MAP_abandoned_mine
Datasets.Description: This digital product is developed from a database of published abandoned mine openings for the province of Nova Scotia. The database is maintained by the Nova Scotia Department of Energy and Mines (NSDEM), Geoscience and Mines Branch (GMB). The digital product was created by the NSDEM GMB staff. The database provides approximate coordinate locations for many of the abandoned mine openings, and also provides a source reference on each mine opening.
Datasets.Summary: To identify the location of abandoned mine openings with the hope of presenting potential mineral rights holders with a province wide overview of the locations of past mineral production and an exploration guide to finding new deposits.
Datasets.Purpose: To identify the location of abandoned mine openings with the hope of presenting potential mineral rights holders with a province wide overview of the locations of past mineral production and an exploration guide to finding new deposits.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_bedrock
Datasets.Description: This digital product is a digital version of Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources (NSDNR) Published Map ME 2000-01, Geological Map of the Province of Nova Scotia, compiled by J.D. Keppie, 2000. The digital product was created by the NSDNR, Mineral Resources Branch (MRB) staff. The original data was compiled and digitized from over 60 maps and sources of information that are noted on the map. The GIS databases were developed from the information contained on this map. The digital product contains layers for geological features such as: bedrock geologic units, faults, geological contacts, isotope ages, other geological features.
Datasets.Summary: The purpose of this data set is to create a digital version of NSDNR Map ME 2000-01. This digital product shows the bedrock geology of the Province of Nova Scotia.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_forest
Datasets.Description: GIS thematic layer containing polygons for all lands in Nova Scotia. Includes water, forest, and non-forest areas, with a primary focus on identifying the attributes of forested land.The source data was obtained by interpretation of 1:10,000 aerial photography and updated by applying change detection algorithms to satellite imagery, and treatment information obtained from various ground sources (GPS, compass and stringbox). New imagery is obtained for approximately 10% of the province each year. In this imagery, only areas enduring distrubance or having a height greater than or equal to 13 metres are reinterpreted. Areas of harvests and partial cuts updated from satellite imagery are locationally correct, but may not have an exact representation of the boundaries due to pixel size. These areas have been entered on the interim between photo interpretation to allow for on-going forestry analysis. The boundaries will be refined as photo re-interpretation occurs.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_riparian_buffer
Datasets.Description: Removal of vegetation adjacent to waterbodies has a major impact on wildlife and aquatic habitat as well as on water quality. The adoption of policy recommendations arising from the HRM Water Resources Management Study (WRMS) could include 20 m. protective buffers for all waterbodies. Buffers could be extended beyond the 20 m. minimum distance by HRM based on local slope and soil conditions however for the purposes of this study waterbodies have been buffered to 20 metres.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_significant_habitat
Datasets.Description:
In the course of their regular duties and through contacts with other agencies, staff of the

Department of Natural Resources become aware of sites with unusual wildlife concentrations,

habitats used by species at risk, or habitats that are few in number within the province.

Recording information about these locations and making it available to appropriate agencies

and personnel, is the goal of the Significant Species and Habitats Project. The Project is

coordinated by the Manager Wildlife Resources, Terrestrial Habitat, Wildlife Division. Data is

assembled and recorded by the Regional Biologists and Wildlife Division staff. This document

explains the policy surrounding data collection, storage and access.

Landowners, resource companies, developers, utility companies, and governments at all levels

have an interest in the location of significant habitats so they can plan their activities

accordingly. Mapping known significant habitats is the first step in the management and

conservation of these sites. The mapping also plays a supportive role in the Department’s

Integrated Resource Management initiative, in impact assessment and natural resource

management planning by private agencies. The Significant Species and Habitat Project’s

overriding philosophy is that conservation of the site can only proceed if those involved have

knowledge of the information.

Project data bases include sensitive information. The widespread interest in significant habitats

data requires a policy that balances information access for management purposes with

information protection to prevent unauthorized or careless use of the sites. In addition, data is

partially collected from non DNR sources. To obtain this data, staff often need to assure the

owners that the information will be kept confidential and only available to persons with a

scientific or conservation interest in the site.

Users of the information should be aware that the data base is not a complete survey of all

significant habitats in the province. It should not be considered a planned inventory, nor

comprehensive.
Datasets.Tags: habitat species migratory bird deer concern
Datasets.Credits:
The Wildlife Division of the Department of Natural Resources, manages the project and is
responsible for project design, data base standards, and data release. They are also responsible
for the accuracy of the data they collect. The Division is responsible for making decisions
relative to the status, distribution, sensitivity to threats and potential impacts of development
on species and their habitats.

There is an extensive list of naturalists and institutions who have provided data to the project.
They are responsible for the accuracy of their data and have committed themselves to sharing
it with persons and institutions who have a scientific or conservation interest in the sites.
Institutional data sources outside DNR include: Acadia University, Canada Department of
Fisheries and Oceans, Canadian Lakes Loon Survey, Canadian Wildlife Service, Cape Breton
Highlands National Park, Fortress Louisbourg National Historic Site, Nova Scotia Museum of
Natural History, and University College of Cape Breton Herbarium.
Datasets.UseConstraints: Contact NSDNR Wildife with any inquiries.
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: In the course of their regu… | Tags: habitat species migratory bird deer concern

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_surficial_geology
Datasets.Description: This digital product is a compilation of surficial geological data of the Halifax Metropolitan area which was defined by Dan Utting using a LiDAR derived bare-earth hillshade model. The LiDAR data was collected by PHB Lasermap, and provided by Halifax Regional Municipality. The data was used to create Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources (NSDNR) Open File Maps OFM ME 2011-001 to 2011-012, compiled by D. J. Utting, 2011. The digital product was created by the NSDNR, Mineral Resources Branch (MRB) staff. The digital product contains layers for geological features such as: age dates, drumlins, eskers, geological contacts, surficial geologic units, ice movement, moraines, meltwater, neatline, station locations and large aggregate quarries.
Datasets.Summary: The purpose of this data set is to create a digital version of the surficial geology of the Halifax Metropolitan and surrounding areas, and to produce 11 new 1:25 000 maps. Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_surficial_geology_ns
Datasets.Description: This digital product (version 2 released as DP ME 1992-03) is a digital version of Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources (NSDNR) Published Map ME 1992-3, Surficial Geology Map of the Province of Nova Scotia, compiled by R.R. Stea, H. Conley and Y. Brown, 1992. The digital product was created by the NSDNR, Mineral Resources Branch (MRB) staff. The digital product was digitized from Map ME 1992-3 and the databases were developed from the information contained on this map. The digital product contains layers for surficial geology features such as: beaches, cirques, deltas, drumlins, eskers, surficial geological units, hummocks, kettles, morraines, meltwater, roche moutonnees, terrace scarps, glacial striations and other geological features. Version 2 of the product was released in 2006 in NAD83 and contained a number of thematic layers which were not included in version 1.
Datasets.Summary: The purpose of this data set is to create a digital version of NSDNR Map ME 92-3. This digital product shows the surficial geology of the Province of Nova Scotia.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_wetland_freshwater
Datasets.Description: The Nova Scotia Wetland Vegetation and Classification Inventory is based on the freshwater and salt marsh wetlands from the Nova Scotia Wetlands and Coastal Habitats Inventory (2000) dataset. This original inventory was developed to delineate and classify fresh and saltwater wetlands and coastal habitats to support policy and legislation, land use planning and impact assessment, environmental monitoring and reporting, and scientific research. All dominant wetlands and coastal habitat features greater than 0.5 hectares including bogs, fens, deep and shallow marshes, seasonally flooded flats, meadows, shrub and wooded swamps, lakeshore wetlands, salt marsh, saline ponds, dune, beach, cliff, and estuarine and marine flats were mapped using 1:10,000 airphoto interpretation. This dataset was integrated into the digital 1:10,000 forest cover from the Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources. Different years of photography were used for the counties. Cumberland County: 1985 and 1995; Colchester County: 1985 and 1994; Inverness, Victoria, Cape Breton, Richmond Counties: 1993; Kings, Annapolis, Queens, Lunenburg, Halifax, Hants Counties: 1992; Guysborough County: 1991; Pictou, Antigonish Counties: 1990 and 1997; Shelburne County: 1989; Yarmouth County: 1988 and 1989; Digby County: 1988. The above inventory took a number of years to complete. It was hoped that Landsat imagery could be used as a less costly and time consuming method of monitoring the changes within these delineated wetlands. At the same time this project was suggested, the new object oriented software program eCognition became available. ECognition uses segmentation which allows for grouping of pixels in a way that relates them to each other, as opposed to single pixels. As well membership functions, custom features, and nearest neighbour techniques can be used to classify the imagery. Essentially, the existing polygon boundaries were used and the classified vegetation types within were rolled up into the wetland types. Within the original wetland polygon it may say for example 20% treed bog and 80% shrub bog, but does not break down where these actually occur within the polygon. This method using eCognition does show where these different areas are.
Datasets.Summary: This product was developed to classify the wetlands in the Nova Scotia Wetlands and Coastal Habitats Inventory (2000) into vegetation types and then to roll up the vegetation into the 5 wetland classes recognized by the Canadian Wetlands Inventory (marsh, swamp, bog, fen, open water). This provided a way to update any changes that occurred in the wetland polygon after the initial inventory based on airphoto interpretation.
Datasets.Purpose: This product was developed to classify the wetlands in the Nova Scotia Wetlands and Coastal Habitats Inventory (2000) into vegetation types and then to roll up the vegetation into the 5 wetland classes recognized by the Canadian Wetlands Inventory (marsh, swamp, bog, fen, open water). This provided a way to update any changes that occurred in the wetland polygon after the initial inventory based on airphoto interpretation.

Datasets.Description: The Muster Point feature class was created for the purposes of EMO with assistance from Halifax Transit. Designated bus stops were identified by Halifax Transit as gathering locations for transportation of people out of an area during an emergency evacuation. A number of meeting locations were also identified outside of Seniors Residential Complexes for the purposes of evacuation. All muster points for Seniors Residential Complexes are named after the Seniors Complex and all muster points at bus stops are names as the location of the bus stop.

Datasets.Description: Proposed routes for the HRM Active Transportation Plan.
Datasets.Summary: The Active Transportation Plan was approved in principle on November 14th, 2006 by Halifax Regional Council. The Active Transportation Plan is a comprehensive document that provides policy direction for the development of an Active Transportation network within HRM. As well, technical guidelines have been created for the planning and design of the network. It is anticipated that promotion and education will be fundamental to the increase in the number of residents using active modes of transportation for their day-to-day activities.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.TRN_taz_travel_time
Datasets.Description: The dataset contains synthetic travel time estimates derived from the municipality’s travel demand model. The model simulates commuter behavior, land use, network conditions, and future scenario testing to predict travel times across different modes of transportation:- Driving → Fully Modeled   Travel times are generated by the Model, accounting for network congestion, road hierarchy, and trip distributions.- Transit → Fully Modeled   Includes bus frequency, stop locations, transfer penalties, and schedule-based wait times.- Walking & Cycling → Simple Calculation (Not Modeled)   Walking: 5 km/h assumed speed applied over network distance.   Cycling: 15 km/h assumed speed applied over network distance.   No congestion or intersection delays considered (basic GIS-based network travel time).This dataset captures both:- Baseline travel times (current conditions)- Future projections based on modeled scenariosEach update may include recalibrated model assumptions, new study areas, and updated land use conditions.
Datasets.Summary:
This dataset provides modeled travel times between Transportation Analysis Zones (TAZs) within the municipality for multiple travel modes including walking, cycling, driving (solo and carpool), and transit (bus, rail, and microtransit). Each record represents a directional travel relationship (origin TAZ → destination TAZ). The data supports commuter studies, accessibility analysis, transportation modeling, and policy evaluation.
The dataset captures synthetic (modeled) estimates that inform planning decisions and public engagement, such as the commuter guide story map.
Datasets.Purpose:
This dataset provides modeled travel times between Transportation Analysis Zones (TAZs) within the municipality for multiple travel modes including walking, cycling, driving (solo and carpool), and transit (bus, rail, and microtransit). Each record represents a directional travel relationship (origin TAZ → destination TAZ). The data supports commuter studies, accessibility analysis, transportation modeling, and policy evaluation.
The dataset captures synthetic (modeled) estimates that inform planning decisions and public engagement, such as the commuter guide story map.
Datasets.Tags: Transportation Analysis Zones (TAZ), Travel Time Modeling, Walking, Cycling, Driving, Transit, Travel Demand Model, Accessibility Studies, Commuter Analysis, Scenario Modeling, Policy Evaluation, Public Engagement, Active Transportation, Urban Mobility
Datasets.Credits:
"This dataset was developed by the municipality’s Transportation Planning Team. Travel times were modeled using a transportation demand model and manual calculations for specific travel modes.
For details on methodology, assumptions, or model updates, contact Adam Lanigan (lanigaa@halifax.ca)."
Datasets.UseConstraints: "This dataset is synthetic and does not represent real-world, observed travel times.Travel times are estimates based on assumptions, which may differ from actual conditions due to traffic congestion, weather, transit delays, construction, or behavioral changes.Driving and Transit travel times are fully modeled, while Walking and Cycling travel times were calculated using static speed assumptions.Not suitable for routing applications, operational planning, or emergency response.Users should refer to metadata for details on model assumptions, base years, and updates."
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: The dataset contains synthetic travel time estimates derived from the municipality’s travel demand m… | Tags: Transportation Analysis Zones (TAZ), Travel Time Modeling, Walking, Cycling, Driving, Transit, Travel Demand Model, Accessibility Studies, Commuter Analysis, Scenario Modeling, Policy Evaluation, Public Engagement, Active Transportation, Urban Mobility

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.TRN_traffic_conflicts
Datasets.Description: The Traffic Conflicts dataset is designed to collect and analyze data on traffic conflicts occurring on the road. This dataset will record the date and time of each conflict and indicate whether an injury has occurred. This dataset was created as a supplementary dataset to the Traffic Collisions dataset in order to track and identify possible locations with safety issues based on near miss encounters between road users or collisions deemed unreportable to police based on NS legislation.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.CEN_2016_DA_AGE_INDV
Datasets.Description: This dataset is an export of the Statistics Canada 2016 Census of Population data for Age and Sex (98-400-X201600) release on May 3, 2017. The original data contains all population numbers for various individual ages, as well as, age ranges for all of Canada. Due to the size of the original dataset, this dataset only contains data for Halifax Regional Municipality and various individual ages per dissemination areas. For more informaiton on population for various age ranges and sex see the CEN_2016_DA_AGE_RANGE dataset
Datasets.Summary: This dataset was created for statistical purposes to offer additional information in regards to population and individual ages and sex.  The table can be used in conjunction with the CEN_dissemination_area_2016 feature class for spatial analysis using the DAUID.

Datasets.Name: SDEADM.NAT_WATERSHED_ASSESSMENT
Datasets.Description:
For complete metadata, see:

R:\Shared Services\GIS\Watershed_Metadata_From_NSDOE\Nova.Scotia.Watershed.Assessment.Program_Part-A_Phase-1_Summary.Report.pdf

The Nova Scotia Watershed Assessment Program (NSWAP) was initiated to increase our knowledge on

the current state of watersheds in Nova Scotia. At this time, there was a knowledge gap on the pattern

of watershed issues we faced. We did not know which watersheds were most impacted or at risk, and

there was no provincial-scale picture available of the status of watersheds in Nova Scotia. Initial

discussions on the NSWAP were initiated by Dr. Shannon Sterling at Dalhousie University in July 2009

and held with members of the Water and Wastewater Branch at Nova Scotia Environment (NSE).

In 2010, a decision was made to implement the NSWAP in two parts (A and B), in order to increase

feasibility. Part A is designed to be an initial and simplified assessment of the watersheds of Nova Scotia.

Nova Scotia Watershed Assessment Project Part A. Summary Report August 2011

with the scope set for completion in a seven-month period (Jan-July 2011). In December 2010, the

NSWAP Part A was launched as the first research project under the Nova Scotia Water Strategy

(Government of Nova Scotia 2010). In January 2011 work began on the project, and it was completed

seven months later, in July 2011.
Datasets.Tags: Watershed
Datasets.Credits:
This project was made possible with in kind contributions from Dalhousie University including salary
support, office space and software licenses. Tom Clair and Ian Dennis for sharing data on Acid
Neutralization Capacity. Fred Whoriskey for help on calculating upstream length from dams. We thank
the various community groups for their support and enthusiasm for the project.
Datasets.MetadataSnippet: F… | Tags: Watershed
